channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Aid Convoy Is Hit in Syria as Cease-Fire Falters and Bombings Resume
item.media:description: Destruction in a government-held neighborhood in Homs, Syria, on Monday.
item.description: The convoy attack and resumed bombings were the strongest signs yet of the unraveling of an agreement between Russia and the United States aimed at restarting peace talks to end the conflict in Syria.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Vladimir Putin Tightens Grip on Russia’s Parliament With Election Rout
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia, center, at a cabinet meeting on Monday in Moscow.
item.description: Nearly complete results showed the president’s ruling United Russia party gaining an absolute majority of seats after elections with record low voter turnout.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Rome Mayor’s Troubled First 3 Months Raise Doubts on Her Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Virginia Raggi, the mayor of Rome, visiting the banks of the Tiber River. Three months after being elected, Ms. Raggi, a lawyer with almost no political experience, appears to be struggling.
item.description: Virginia Raggi, elected as the city’s first female mayor in a shining moment for the anti-establishment movement, appears to be floundering.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Threlkeld Journal: In English Lake District, Tradition and Conservation Clash
item.media:description: Hikers on Blencathra, in the Lake District in England. Two years ago, ramblers, climbers and hill-lovers banded together to try to buy the peak, but the effort has now fizzled.
item.media:credit: Phil Moore for The New York Times
item.description: The fate of a farm illustrates the struggle to balance farming, environmental renewal and rapid tourism growth in one of the country’s most scenic regions.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Laser Scans Unveil a Network of Ancient Cities in Cambodia
item.media:description: A woman at work beside ruins in the Angkor region of Cambodia.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: Beyond the famed Angkor Wat temple, a technology known as lidar is allowing archaeologists to map and find the ancient Khmer empire’s intricate urban landscape.
item.dc:creator: JULIA WALLACE
item.category: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

item.title: Modi Retains Broad Support in India Despite Criticism, Poll Finds
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in New Delhi on Friday. Despite slow progress on economic reforms, and religious and caste tensions, 81 percent of Indians had a favorable view of Mr. Modi.
item.description: The Pew Research Center found that 81 percent of Indians had a favorable view of Mr. Modi, despite stalled economic reforms and social tensions.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Blazes in Southeast Asia May Have Led to Deaths of Over 100,000, Study Says
item.media:description: Palangkaraya, Indonesia, during the haze last year. A study estimated that 91,600 people in Indonesia, 6,500 in Malaysia and 2,200 in Singapore may have died prematurely because of exposure to fine particle pollution from burning forests.
item.description: The vast number of cases were in Indonesia, where the government claimed last year that only 19 people died.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Kinshasa, Congo, Is Locked Down as Protests Erupt Against Joseph Kabila
item.media:description: Congolese protesters in Kinshasa, the capital, on Monday. They are calling on President Joseph Kabila to abide by term limits and step down.
item.description: Many Congolese fear that President Joseph Kabila is trying to wiggle out of term limits and hold onto power indefinitely.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Colombia’s Leader Says Peace Deal Rests on People’s Ability to Forgive
item.media:description: Rodrigo Londoño, leader of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, speaking Saturday at the opening ceremony of the National Guerrilla Conference in Llanos del Yarí, Colombia.
item.description: President Juan Manuel Santos cited challenges still to come ahead of a referendum on a deal that would end Latin America’s last major guerrilla conflict.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Obama, at the U.N., Cites Iraq Gains and Urges Steady Nerves at Home
item.media:description: President Obama meeting with Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi of Iraq on Monday.
item.description: The president visited the United Nations General Assembly against the backdrop of a stabbing attack in Minnesota and a weekend bombing in New York.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Justin Trudeau: Bringing Canada Back to the Global Stage
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Hong Kong on Sept. 6. During last year’s election, he promised to again make Canada an active participant in global affairs.
item.description: The new prime minister has said, “Canada is back,” and has admitted refugees and promised to admit refugees, fight climate change and play a role in United Nations peacekeeping efforts.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: President Obama: A Farewell, Highlighting Diplomacy and Refugees
item.media:description: President Obama boarded Air Force One in Maryland on Sunday, on his way to New York for the United Nations General Assembly.
item.description: In the last United Nations General Assembly session of his presidency, Mr. Obama will hark back to an agenda he laid out in his first General Assembly address.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Theresa May: A Big Debut as the Voice of Britain
item.media:description: Theresa May’s first speech at the United Nations General Assembly, on Tuesday, will also be her first foreign policy speech as prime minister of Britain.
item.description: The new prime minister is not associated with any particular foreign policy, but she will have to come up with the elements of one for her speech.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: François Hollande: Facing ISIS Threats in France, and Sagging Polls
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France at a European economic meeting in Athens on Sept. 9. He is trying to find a way forward for the European Union after Britain’s vote to exit the bloc.
item.description: The French president is certain to speak at the United Nations about Syria and the future of Europe, but solid solutions have so far been elusive.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Michel Temer: Striving for Legitimacy as Brazil’s New Leader
item.media:description: President Michel Temer is tasked with reassuring Brazilians that his ascension will bring change without too much disruption.
item.description: The Brazilian president faces a balancing act after a divisive impeachment battle ousted a rival, Dilma Rousseff, allowing him to ascend.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: France Fears Becoming Too ‘Anglo-Saxon’ in Its Treatment of Minorities
item.media:description: Nicolas Sarkozy, the former French president, wrote in his latest book: “We are not like the Anglo-Saxons who let communities live side by side, ignoring each other and at any rate not mixing.”
item.description: The French worry that they’re slipping into the American and British model, which they perceive as keeping ethnicities apart, instead of forming a single identity.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: At Least 7 Afghan Police Officers Killed in Errant U.S. Strike, Officials Say
item.media:description: The Afghan Army patrolling Tirin Kot, which has held off Taliban insurgents with the help of American airstrikes.
item.description: A police post on the main road into Tirin Kot in southern Afghanistan was under assault, and an airstrike hit the post instead of the attackers, an official said.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and TAIMOOR SHAH

item.title: Angela Merkel Accepts Responsibility for Party’s Losses in Berlin Election
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel at a meeting of her Christian Democrats in Berlin on Monday, a day after the party’s poor showing at the polls.
item.description: After the latest defeat for the German chancellor’s center-right party, she tried to convince voters that she was not out of touch with their anger over an influx of migrants.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Examining the U.N.’s Record on Urgent Global Challenges
item.description: An assessment of the organization’s performance on refugees, war and peace, human rights, terrorism, gender equality and climate change.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: South Korea Says It’s Unlikely to Help North Recover From Flood
item.media:description: Repairing a flood-damaged train track in North Hamgyong Province, North Korea, last week.
item.description: The North had not asked for help, the South Korean government said, reaffirming its hard-line stance after the North’s fifth nuclear test this month.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Syria’s Unraveling Truce: ‘My Children Woke Up, Again, to Explosions’
item.media:description: Syrian children listening to songs on Friday at an underground amusement park in Erbeen, east of Damascus.
item.description: Moments of relief during a cease-fire have not created a sense of security or alleviated the country’s misery.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: A Paris Shop Turns On the Charm, and South Koreans Swoon
item.media:description: Tourists shopping at Pharmacie Monge in Paris last month.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Pharmacie Monge’s cosmetics and a nod from a blogger drew South Korean tourists in. The hiring of Korean-speaking employees kept them coming in droves.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: What in the World: In Britain’s Parliament, a Crowded House Bursting With Lords
item.media:description: A parliamentary session this month at the House of Lords in London. There is no limit on membership, and members generally serve for life.
item.description: Efforts to overhaul the House of Lords, reduce its membership or abolish it altogether have produced more noise than fundamental change.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: After Shimon Peres, Israel Will No Longer Be Young
item.media:description: Shimon Peres, photographed in 2013.
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.description: Following the former president’s stroke, the country is in danger of losing the last of its founding generation.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Age of Distrust
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.description: Democracies are undermined by the growing belief the system is rigged in favor of elites.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Opinion: England’s Forgotten Muslim History
item.media:description: Murad III, left, Elizabeth I, right.
item.media:credit: Ullstein Bild, via Getty Images (left); The Print Collector/Getty Images (right)
item.description: Isolated from Europe, Elizabeth I turned to the Islamic world.
item.dc:creator: JERRY BROTTON
item.category: Elizabeth I, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: At the Hajj, Facing Islam’s Inconsistent Embrace of Women
item.media:description: Women at the hajj, clockwise from left: on Ajyad Street, one of the main thoroughfares leading to the Grand Mosque in Mecca; Indonesian women rested on a sidewalk in the tent city of Mina, where nearly 2 million pilgrims slept for three days as part of their hajj rites; and the Times correspondent Diaa Hadid during the hajj.
item.description: Our reporter, on her first hajj, says she “was at once frustrated by Islam’s nitpicky strictures on women’s dress and embraced by its warm sisterhood.”
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
